5C7EE5240959438BA2142E21CAC25890.description: A compound word is formed when two individual words are put together to make a new word.

D63AE4C9512A4093B01E0EA48A336899.description: Adding the suffix <ed> to the ending of a word indicates it already happened (changes the tense).

7D39A05A772B4E5E9ADF6F21F2196131.description: Adding the suffix <s> or <es> to the ending of a word can indicate more than one (plural).

2CB94387EEF54FD3ADC028DE40997AAC.description: Suffixes are morphemes located at the ending of words.

9F4BD35E7597439682BCF59702745A8A.description: A base is the main morpheme (the smallest unit of a word that holds meaning) in a word.

FEBD0EBDFE7D47C7A3581B69F2728FAB.description: An antonym is a word that has the opposite meaning of another word.

6BB8B1A18A41404CB2510A7CE2A34AC5.description: A synonym is a word that has a similar meaning to another word.

DF44A77744A44362B64C91B549501171.description: Vocabulary development includes some academic words (tier 3 words) from read alouds and texts.

56DD0B1E92AA414EB3F952C0E4398A78.description: Vocabulary development includes learning (tier 2) words that are unknown to most learners, critical for comprehending new texts, useful and may be encountered in the future.

E53AA38578264A4B99DDE220856EB953.description: Students analyze word formation and meaning.

E35337566A1845B88A117708BED05E21.description: Vocabulary: Communication and comprehension are improved by understanding word meaning and structures.

1D09BA84684F40F1B87AFAA5F5C1FA4B.description: Adjust verbal or non-verbal language according to a variety of situation.

A4745D601B7B4F868E897326AF050E4E.description: Examine verbal and non-verbal language that is appropriate for a variety of situations.

4989EFA4C5024FBB98F305525C56F7D1.description: Listen to and follow two-step instructions.

7C77881731764AA18DBCB600CC91BD81.description: Contribute to discussions as a listener and speaker.

727E9EFE22594F10BC0ED0204F8CC42C.description: Respond orally to questions during discussions.

42C36F39AF1D48F5BC56C172937B7B23.description: Ask questions to clarify information during discussions.

DE5AE18A916745F9BB130F7723DFE8FC.description: Present stories, songs, poems, or dramatizations individually or as part of a group.

75AE60FAC1D3454B88C386341F6F3E04.description: Adjust speaking volume, tone, and pace for a variety of situations.

E1E3356A24AB403C907B779E8F97907C.description: Share experiences, ideas, and information with appropriate volume, tone, and pace.

72D4C3EC17044E2C92D58F362F1BC384.description: Discuss special rules (protocols) about how, when, or with whom stories are shared.

6E3279ED52904B14BEA75B79C547EFA9.description: Recognize kinship in a variety of oral stories.

328D988777474694A08BF131E9E4C324.description: Practise listening and speaking skills through sharing oral stories.

E6590C19F7CA4968B577EDF24C9EE82B.description: Verbal and non-verbal language can be used to communicate messages.

E2F16E9A89AB49258B295CC3DD01C78A.description: Listening is an active process that supports understanding.

5CF8BBC44D3D4B219D3410B22E66F4D0.description: Listening and speaking can be used to share messages in a variety of situations.

0D4D7C5F9D85419C97EAD0D8A195412B.description: Oral traditions can provide opportunities to learn and think about kinship.

A00F59196BDE43E9AC9071F5EBA97E6C.description: Messages can be shared without sounds or words (non-verbally) through body language, such as eye contact, movements and facial expressions.

055C3A3D5BB74ECE98E9C092793C741E.description: Messages can be shared through sounds and words (verbally).

9B15D13F52D54AF2B4C8768337466D7A.description: Listening processes can look different for individuals or within communities.

2AAD7DC2BE4D4179BCDA7C1E465A88C2.description: Listening includes asking and responding to questions.

8F2266616EDD4CFBA89DA3E49497D4AA.description: Listening involves maintaining attention and focus.

7732A312A90346C29A510335A498471F.description: Speakers can indicate differences in character, key ideas, and events through changes in volume, tone, and pace.

76D486F0104D4199B34186667C269A3E.description: The speaking voice is supported through full, deep breaths that can affect volume, tone, and pace.

2847072A17874A51A5C55DAFA4D8E48B.description: The volume, emotional quality (tone), and rate of speech (pace) can affect the meaning or clarity of a message.

AA1B49D8E9BC4810B9DB693F16E7A856.description: Listening and speaking skills can be developed through discussions, songs, poems, stories, dramatizations and presentations.

C7C812290EC24B859CE2AC768FAA9E29.description: Communities may have special rules (protocols) about how, when, or with whom stories are shared.

A07BAE1F08A24FA1AEA1464334C2A8BD.description: Oral stories are highly valued in many communities.

4F7BA15376D44BE387238BD6F91C9B16.description: Stories that are shared through listening and speaking (oral traditions) can be handed down from generation to generation.

8E70A52192A84ED7902CA39A93E218E1.description: Students develop listening and speaking skills through sharing stories and information.

E3E6DEE2BA604713933DBDDDF791127D.description: Oral Language: Listening and speaking form the foundation for literacy development and improve communication, collaboration, and respectful mutual understanding.

65B601165FDF4048AF1CBB9C1FA77AFE.description: Determine if a poem rhymes or if it does not.

3827940A22DF41BD857A9DCCCA7F5C3A.description: Share connections between personal experiences and messages represented through poetry and song.

FC8F87B71E6042D9AC1180E4F853D2F6.description: Examine ways that information can be organized and shared to support learning.

E656C9C3B9C348D1B48C628537E215B1.description: Examine information provided by the narrator in a story or message.

D95FE4E771B44049991700B20FFBF29E.description: Create imaginative representations or dramatizations of stories that include characters, setting, and events.

7F5A2B5F7F75446D900BB657CF7E5054.description: Describe story elements within a variety of imaginary stories.

F4E87339DC2848DCACD3E7FED10D556E.description: Include a variety of features to help organize or clarify personal messages.

E0C2F100134C4174A7B3C05BEF65322D.description: Examine a variety of features that help clarify messages.

167F2D2D9CE84C749E47478B38FA30F7.description: Examine sentences that start with a capital letter, have spaces between words, and end with punctuation.

C2DB008E00A54CF98B898A0301B9BF90.description: Read print with accurate one-to-one word matching.

EC07855CA027453C93F5B0A741176C40.description: Read print from left to right with a return sweep.

752DC45321624BCB812363A99C869EAC.description: Identify the title and author or creator of a variety of digital or non-digital messages.

57485D3D4E1A4DC2924BE3FD66A15C72.description: Identify messages in a variety of environmental print.

8DCD5599D4334C998CC84839E04AF706.description: Identify the beginning, middle, and ending in a message.

765E7B57EC24477FAAA5C7A059BB02A8.description: Discuss forms used to organize messages.

F41E995A8F5A4F5EB22FEF5627CCDC09.description: Describe the differences between messages that are imaginary (fiction) or real (non-fiction).

04E0C315AEE1490A890FE5DCB37298C1.description: Discuss reasons for messages to be shared.

E6642BDA2463415DA1A4F556D044F725.description: Poetry explores ideas and feelings and helps us to connect to our experiences.

EE315266209248F1B99ECA01A220A5EF.description: Messages that share ideas and information that are real or true (non-fiction) can encourage thinking and build knowledge.

D516C3718B0A437193E54AE3FDCF7D17.description: Knowledge can be built and expanded by exploring stories and ideas that are imaginary (fictional).

B63BA1EB6A3E4585BEF55FDAEFFD0E39.description: Messages can be clarified and organized using features.

580748BDB7534731A8B489EA8C34062D.description: Ideas and information can be organized by purpose, form, or structure.

FFA19E23572D49B7AD01412D1DA21F75.description: Some poems rhyme and some do not.

0CBEEAB805D146B8A7A7721B492F080F.description: Poems and songs can contain words and phrases that rhyme.

0CEDC4B8DE634D4BA3361C59829031B5.description: Poems can describe ideas and feelings in creative and joyful ways.

54DEF9C558234FA188B212F428C68F71.description: Informational texts have structures, including main idea, supporting details and sequencing.

EC79F7F407B44E7CAE5B951B481B0C58.description: Real information or ideas (non-fiction) can be shared through digital or non-digital forms, including personal stories, instructions and observations.

41E21C46D222457D9A596ED415BE9314.description: A narrator is the person or character telling a story.

EBB893F05AA048D8AF7029956E4CB87B.description: Stories have structures (elements), including characters, setting and events.

BE836E459CF8473D8D9F88D9BEA1FA3C.description: A fable is a short story that has a moral and often includes animals as characters.

9307F17AAEC946CE860C1A1B6A0C57A7.description: Imaginary (fictional) stories include fairy tales, fables and realistic stories.

1FAF2DD0C3AA49D194B5CA6B7450BFF8.description: Features that clarify and organize messages can be digital or non-digital, including colour, font, or bolding and titles and headings.

FD680C3DF5BE47DDB0300E08BB0955A3.description: Books and other forms of print are organized in specific ways (concepts of print): A book has a title and an author, Print is read from left to right and top to bottom with a return sweep, Each print word represents one spoken word when read aloud, Sentences are made up of words, Words are separated by spaces in sentences. and Punctuation marks can signal the end of a sentence.

CB49309A9962491CB5EBF8383EA7D478.description: Environmental print includes signs, symbols, and words.

F7A53F8A28DA4EF4B9E6190E9BE451AB.description: Stories, both real and imaginary, can follow a structure, including beginning, middle and ending.

605446B528FA4672AAF988783708FE16.description: Messages can be shared in a variety of forms, including books, stories, pictures and land.

2E8081B7D626497C908226035A2102E3.description: Messages can be shared digitally or non-digitally through reading, writing, listening, speaking, viewing and representing.

6D353BC70CC74BEE8D94042EB2A59851.description: Messages can depict ideas and information that are imaginary (fiction) or real (non-fiction).

13A2BEEFDB0A413B921D0FEB3368CAFA.description: Messages can be shared for different reasons (purposes), including to learn, have fun, and stay safe.

9AC5134549E54B398B241225576A4F9B.description: Students examine ways that messages can be organized and presented for different purposes.

62B723FC5A234077ABEEEC1DB85FDE19.description: Text Forms and Structures: Identifying and applying text forms and structures improves understanding of content, literary style, and our rich language traditions.
